column3: Jup and Top, who knew when to be silent, ran in advance.

column2: The cart came out, the gate was reclosed, and the onager, led by Pencroft, advanced at a slow pace.
column3: The cart came out, the gate was reclosed, and the onager, led by Pencroft, advanced at a slow pace.

column2: Certainly, it would have been safer to have taken a different road than that which led straight from the corral to Granite House, but the cart would have met with great difficulties in moving under the trees.
column3: Certainly, it would have been safer to have taken a different road than that which led straight from the corral to Granite House, but the cart would have met with great difficulties in moving under the trees.

column2: It was necessary, therefore, to follow this way, although it was well known to the convicts.
column3: It was necessary, therefore, to follow this way, although it was well known to the convicts.

column2: Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett walked one on each side of the cart, ready to answer to any attack.
column3: Cyrus Harding and Gideon Spilett walked one on each side of the cart, ready to answer to any attack.

column2: However, it was not probable that the convicts would have yet left the plateau of Prospect Heights.
column3: However, it was not probable that the convicts would have yet left the plateau of Prospect Heights.

column2: Neb's note had evidently been written and sent as soon as the convicts had shown themselves there.
column3: Neb's note had evidently been written and sent as soon as the convicts had shown themselves there.

column2: Now, this note was dated six o'clock in the morning, and the active orang, accustomed to come frequently to the corral, had taken scarcely three quarters of an hour to cross the five miles which separated it from Granite House.
column3: Now, this note was dated six o'clock in the morning, and the active orang, accustomed to come frequently to the corral, had taken scarcely three quarters of an hour to cross the five miles which separated it from Granite House.

column2: They would, therefore, be safe at that time, and if there was any occasion for firing, it would probably not be until they were in the neighborhood of Granite House. However, the colonists kept a strict watch.
column3: They would, therefore, be safe at that time, and if there was any occasion for firing, it would probably not be until they were in the neighborhood of Granite House. However, the colonists kept a strict watch.

column2: Top and Jup, the latter armed with his club, sometimes in front, sometimes beating the wood at the sides of the road, signalized no danger.
column3: Top and Jup, the latter armed with his club, sometimes in front, sometimes beating the wood at the sides of the road, signalized no danger.

column2: The cart advanced slowly under Pencroft's guidance.
column3: The cart advanced slowly under Pencroft's guidance.

column2: It had left the corral at half-past seven.
column3: It had left the corral at half past seven.

column2: An hour after, four out of the five miles had been cleared, without any incident having occurred.
column3: An hour after, four out of the five miles had been cleared, without any incident having occurred.

column2: The road was as deserted as all that part of the Jacamar Wood which lay between the Mercy and the lake.
column3: The road was as deserted as all that part of the Jacamar Wood which lay between the Mercy and the lake.

column2: There was no occasion for any warning.
column3: There was no occasion for any warning.

column2: The wood appeared as deserted as on the day when the colonists first landed on the island.
column3: The wood appeared as deserted as on the day when the colonists first landed on the island.

column2: They approached the plateau.
column3: They approached the plateau.

column2: Another mile and they would see the bridge over Creek Glycerine.
column3: Another mile and they would see the bridge over Creek Glycerine.

column2: Cyrus Harding expected to find it in its place; supposing that the convicts would have crossed it, and that, after having passed one of the streams which enclosed the plateau, they would have taken the precaution to lower it again, so as to keep open a retreat.
column3: Cyrus Harding expected to find it in its place; supposing that the convicts would have crossed it, and that, after having passed one of the streams which enclosed the plateau, they would have taken the precaution to lower it again, so as to keep open a retreat.

column2: At length an opening in the trees allowed the sea-horizon to be seen. But the cart continued its progress, for not one of its defenders thought of abandoning it.
column3: At length an opening in the trees allowed the sea horizon to be seen. But the cart continued its progress, for not one of its defenders thought of abandoning it.

column2: At that moment Pencroft stopped the onager, and in a hoarse voice,--
column3: At that moment Pencroft stopped the onager, and in a hoarse voice,--

column2: Oh! the villains! he exclaimed.
column3: Oh! the villains! he exclaimed.

column2: And he pointed to a thick smoke rising from the mill, the sheds, and the buildings at the poultry-yard.
column3: And he pointed to a thick smoke rising from the mill, the sheds, and the buildings at the poultry yard.

column2: A man was moving about in the midst of the smoke.
column3: A man was moving about in the midst of the smoke.

column2: It was Neb.
column3: It was Neb.

column2: His companions uttered a shout.
column3: His companions uttered a shout.

column2: He heard, and ran to meet them.
column3: He heard, and ran to meet them.

column2: The convicts had left the plateau nearly half-an-hour before, having devastated it!
column3: The convicts had left the plateau nearly half an hour before, having devastated it!

column2: And Mr. Herbert? asked Neb.
column3: And mr Herbert? asked Neb.

column2: Gideon Spilett returned to the cart.
column3: Gideon Spilett returned to the cart.

column2: Herbert had lost consciousness!
column3: Herbert had lost consciousness!
